definition[0]: to break with a sudden sharp noise, or to make something do this
example[0]: A twig snapped under my feet.
example[1]: The wind snapped branches and power lines.
example[2]: The teacher snapped the chalk in two and gave me a piece.
example[3]: I snapped the ends off the beans and dropped them into a bowl.
definition[1]: to move into a particular position suddenly, making a short sharp noise, or to make something move like this
example[5]: The pieces just snap together like this.
example[6]: The policeman snapped the handcuffs around her wrist.
definition[2]: to say something quickly in an angry way
example[8]: He snapped at Walter for no reason.
definition[3]: to suddenly stop being able to control your anger, anxiety, or other feelings in a difficult situation
example[9]: The stress began to get to her, and one morning she just snapped.
example[10]: Something inside him snapped, and he hit her.
definition[4]: if an animal such as a dog snaps, it tries to bite you
example[11]: The dog started snapping at my heels.
example[12]: Dave snapped a picture of me and Sonia.
definition[6]: to end a series of events – used especially in newspapers
example[13]: The Rockets snapped a seven-game losing streak by beating Portland.
definition[7]: a sudden loud sound, especially made by something breaking or closing
example[14]: He shut the book with a snap.
definition[8]: a photograph taken quickly and often not very skilfully
definition[9]: a small metal fastener on clothes that works when you press its two parts together
definition[10]: a card game in which players put down one card after another and try to be the first to shout ‘Snap!’ when there are two cards that are the same
definition[11]: used when you see two things that are exactly the same
example[17]: Hey, snap! My hat’s the same as yours.
definition[12]: said in the game of snap when two cards that are the same are put down
